title-group.article-title: Modeling Competition Between Mobile and Desktop Personal Computer LCD Panels Based on Segment Reporting Sales Information

author-notes.corresp: Bi-Huei Tsai, Department of Management Science, National Chiao Tung University, 1001 Ta-Hsueh Road, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan. Email: bhtsai@faculty.nctu.edu.tw

abstract.p: This investigation employs the Lotka–Volterra model to explore the market competitions between the mobile and desktop personal computer (PC) liquid crystal display (LCD) panels. The sales volumes of desktop and mobile PC LCD panels from each LCD company’s segment reporting income statements are summarized into the global sale volumes of the two specific products. Equilibrium analysis is conducted to analyze whether the quarterly sales volume of mobile and desktop PC panels reach the stable equilibrium by the Lyapunov function. This work examines the forecast accuracy of the Lotka–Volterra model. The parameter estimation results of the Lotka–Volterra model show the commensalism relationship between the mobile and the desktop PC LCD panels. The analyses indicate that when making a purchasing decision, a mobile PC is the first choice for consumers who care more about product innovation, quality, and mobility. After purchasing a mobile PC and becoming familiar with its operation, consumers may find that the computing ability and screen size of a mobile PC are too limited; therefore, consumers would purchase a desktop PC. The results of this study will provide the LCD industries insights concerning appropriate investment strategies to maintain competitive advantages. Equilibrium analysis results demonstrate that the quarterly sales volume of the mobile and desktop PC panels will reach stable equilibrium around 2020, maintaining the quarterly sale amount stabilized at 59,269 and 79,503 thousand pieces for desktop and mobile PC LCD panels, respectively. Finally, the analysis results show that Lotka–Volterra equations predict the global sales volumes of mobile PC and desktop PC panels accurately.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This article mainly utilizes the sales information in the segment reporting income statements to indicate the competitive and complementary relations between sales of mobile and desktop personal computers (PCs). Annual income statements only publicize the sales revenues of the entire product catalogue of each company. Previous studies in accounting employ total sales revenues summarized by all the products in the whole company from annual income statements to measure the firm’s performance (e.g., Behn & Riley, 1999; Leitch & Lamminmaki, 2011), but total sales revenues fail to measure the performance subject to the specific product. This study, for the first time, isolates two specific products—liquid crystal displays (LCDs) in desktop and mobile PCs—from the segment reporting income statements of each LCD company in the world into the global sale volumes of desktop and mobile PC LCD panels to predict the sale volume of desktop and mobile PC LCD panels. Koku (2010) interpreted that managers in high-tech firms must weigh investment expenditures against the projected sales information that could be generated from the product innovation. Givoly and Shi (2008) emphasized the probable economic benefits and certain recoverability about the capital investments. Thus, the sale prediction of PC LCD panels in our research can serve as a valuable reference for economic benefits and capital investment in high-tech industries.

PCs are mainly categorized into two: desktop and mobile. A mobile PC panel accounts for around 30% of the value of a mobile PC, while a desktop PC LCD panel accounts for around 70% of the value of a desktop PC LCD monitor. The numbers of these high proportions (30% and 70%) show that the panel is critical in the LCD industry. Especially by 2011, the annual sales volume of mobile PC panels and desktop PC around the world achieved 500,463 thousand pieces. Among them, mobile PC panels took up 303,997 thousand pieces, while desktop PC panels accounted for 196,465 thousand pieces. Besides, a series of LCD panel innovations combining the functions of tablet PC with notebooks enable PCs to include multiple functions, including telecommunication, photography, word processing, audio-video, and entertainment. This large sales volume and function versatility showed how important PC LCD panels are in the LCD or PC industry. Manufacturers of panels coordinate their production and distribution resources to best suit the needs for desktop or mobile PCs in the market. Therefore, the prediction of sales volumes of mobile PC LCD panels and desktop PC LCD panels is very important.

Because the LCD panel is an essential part of PC, the sales volume of LCD panels has direct correlation with the sales volume of PCs. Because mobile and desktop PCs substitute each other in computing and storage functions, the sales of mobile PCs and desktop PCs maintain a competitive relationship. Mobile PC has higher mobility and better access to the Internet, but its computing ability is limited by the size. However, desktop PC has larger hard disk capacity, abundant memory, multiple USB slots, and sufficient space for comprehensive computer hardware, making desktop PCs superior to mobile PCs in terms of function and computing speed. After purchasing mobile PCs, business people and students might buy desktop PCs to address the needs for higher speed and better function. This way, mobile PCs and desktop PCs sales are complementary to each other. When predicting the sale of LCD panels for mobile and desktop PCs, considering the intertwined relationship of mobile and desktop PCs is a pressing concern.

However, most previous studies applied conventional diffusion theory to determine market dynamics via Bass model (Bass, 1969; Girifalco, 1991). Tsai (2013) applied a typical logistical S-curve to identify product diffusion patterns. Tsai, Li, and Lee (2010) also employed the Bass model to examine the market dynamics of LCD TV panels. The Bass model assumes a monopolistic market (Bass, 1969, 2004; Teng, Grover, & Guttler, 2002), such that the complementary or competitive relation among mobile and desktop LCD panel is ignored. Bias will incur if only the conventional S-curve model is employed to explain the sales volume of the mobile and desktop PC panels. Therefore, this article attempts to use the Lotka–Volterra model to explore the relationship between mobile PC and desktop LCD panels in the LCD panels industry. This work for the first time applies the Lotka–Volterra model to address the effects of interactive cooperation or competition on PC panels.

The Lotka–Volterra model was developed to model interaction between two competing species based on the logistic curve (Kamakura & Balasubramanian, 1987; Norton & Bass, 1987) and extended to analyze technological diffusion in competitive or collaborative markets (Tang & Zhang, 2005; Tsai & Li, 2009, 2011; Watanabe, Kondo, & Nagamatsu, 2003). This study utilizes the estimated parameters of our proposed Lotka–Volterra model to comprehend the competitive or collaborative interactions between mobile and desktop PC LCD panels. In addition, equilibrium analysis is further conducted to explore whether the sales volume of mobile and desktop PC panels reach the stable equilibrium using Lyapunov functions. Finally, this work examines whether Lotka–Volterra models contain good predictive ability to predict the sales volumes of the global panel manufacturing industry. The results of equilibrium analysis show that mobile and desktop PC LCD panels coexist in market. The results of forecast ability exhibit that Lotka–Volterra models precisely forecast the LCD panel diffusions.

The utilization of segment reporting data and proposed predictive model in our research represents a major step forward in the fields of management accounting, highlighted by the following three contributions: unique accounting data, model specification, and applicability to industrial analysis. In reference to unique accounting data, this work collects the sales volume data of specific products in all company’s segment reports and transforms the sales volume data of specific products in all company’s segment report into the global sales volume of the specific product. This study uses the sale relationship between mobile and desktop PC LCD panels as quantitative indicators for measuring the competitive and complementary interactions across various products in the high-tech industry.

Referring to model specifications, this study is the first to construct a model that incorporates competitive and complementary relationships among various products. For applicability in management, our proposed modified model can be applied to forecast the product interactions between specified products in other high-tech industries. Other high-tech products, such as TFT-LCD (thin film transistor liquid crystal display), computers, communications, information technology, and consumer electronics, display the same characteristics as the PCs and LCDs with regard to capital overhead and long-term cost recovery. Thus, the proposed model is applicable to forecasting these high-tech products as well.

Ratnatunga and Balachandran (2009) focused on carbon allowances issue and suggested the necessity of carbon business accounting to evaluate the benefits of investing low–carbon dioxide (CO2) emission technologies or costs of carbon regularity compliance. This study is consistent with the spirit of Ratnatunga and Balachandran in the application of management accounting profession outside the annual financial report in achieving management targets. Our investigation analyzes LCD-based products that are subject to various consumer groups, market segments, and technology levels. Time-series sales volumes of different panels are summarized and predicted as the basis of long-term investment in product innovations and capital investments. This study implies that although the generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) do not oblige companies to disclose the sales and profitability information of each product, such information is still significant in terms of investments decisions concerning capital expenditure, product competiveness, and management accounting. The analysis results of our investigation confirm the important role of segment reporting subject to specific products.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: LCD firms, including Touch Product King (TPK) holding companies, Samsung, LG Corp., currently develop high-priced products such as three-dimensional (3D) LCD monitors, ultrathin LCD monitors, and touch screen monitors that are implemented on mobile and desktop PCs. These progressively developed technologies will continuously create a new niche in a seemingly saturated market of PC and LCD industries. Koku (2009) has confirmed that stock markets react to new product announcements in the computer industry.

Figure 1 illustrates the cumulative sales volumes of global mobile and desktop PC LCD panels. Mobile PC LCD panels show a substantial increase after 2009, a growth that was higher than that of desktop PC. After 2009, the mobile PC curve is steeper than desktop PC curve, so the quarterly sales volumes of mobile PC exceeded that of desktop PC. Since 2009, desktop PC LCD panel has gradually lost its attractiveness to stimulate the purchasing desire of customers. The LCD panels that desktop PCs utilize are further limited in terms of sales volume growth. Especially, the world’s desktop PC LCD panels are mainly manufactured in China, and then shipped to other countries; therefore high import tariffs must be paid. In addition to the import tariffs, the cost of Chinese labors has gradually increased in recently years, so the current gross profit margin of LCD industry is only less than 5%. Labor force and high import tariffs further enhances the intraindustry competition, constraining the sales of LCD panels used in desktop PCs.

sec.p: However, the market of the mobile PC has grown substantially in the past few years. After 2011, tablet PCs also successfully absorbed a great number of consumers. Because tablet PCs belongs to mobile PCs, the sales volume of mobile PC LCD panels will increase consistently. Market Intelligence and Consulting Institute (MIC) statistical reports forecast that the global market for notebook will increase 4.3% in 2012.

sec.title: Data and Sample
sec.p: Basically, we categorize information technology products into two types: desktop and mobile. In this research, the desktop PC category is defined as server, workstation, and desktop PC, with a focus on the speed of computation. The desktop PC LCD panels are display devices connected with desktop PCs, namely, desktop monitors. The mobile PC category is defined as notebook, mininote, ultra notebook, and tablet, with a portable function. The mobile PC LCD panels are display panels of PCs which meet all PC criteria but are designed to be easily moved from place to place. In our sample products, the best resolution for desktop PC LCD panels is as high as 3840 × 2400 and for mobile PC LCD panels 2560 × 1600. The lowest resolution for desktop PC LCD panels is 800 × 600, and for mobile PC LCD panels 800 × 480. The size of desktop PC LCD panels in our sample ranges from 12.1 to 30 inches, while the size of desktop PC LCD panels ranges from 5 to 19 inches. Mobility, energy-saving, and convenience have priority in mobile PC LCD panels, whereas picture display quality, wide color gamut, and high resolution have priority in desktop PC LCD panels.

This article mainly utilizes the sales volume data in the commercial sector reporting income statements for mobile and desktop PC LCD panels. Quarterly global LCD shipments of mobile and desktop PCs, taken as sales in this work, are obtained from Display Research databases. The study period lasts from the first quarter of 2001 to the first quarter of 2011, for a total of 44 quarters. This work divides our sample period into two periods: the training period from the first quarter of 2001 to the fourth quarter of 2010 and the test period from the first quarter of 2011 to the fourth quarter of 2011. Parameters of the proposed model are optimized using the data in the training period, and the forecasting capabilities of different models are compared using the data in the test period.

Table 1 lists the descriptive statistics of desktop PCs and mobile PCs. The average quarterly sale volume of desktop PC LCD panels is greater than that of mobile PC LCD panels. However, the maximum sale volume of mobile PC LCD panels is greater than that of desktop PC LCD panels, because the quarterly sale of mobile PC LCD panels has increased rapidly and exceeded that of desktop PC LCD panels since 2009. Generally, the quarterly sales volumes of desktop PC LCD panels maintain in the interval between 40,000 and 51,000 thousand pieces during the period from 2005 to 2011. Conversely, the quarterly sales volumes of mobile PC LCD panels are less than 20,000 thousand pieces before 2007, but substantially increases up to 80,000 thousand pieces in the third quarter of 2011. The quarterly sales volumes of mobile PC LCD panels in 2011 are almost 4 times as large as that prior to 2007.

sec.p: The self-influence coefficient β2 of desktop PC LCD panel itself is positive and significant, and b2 is positive as well, indicating the competitiveness within the desktop PC industry suppresses its growth rate. The empirical results imply that after purchasing a desktop PC, consumers would not continue buying desktop PCs because it occupies a larger space and has a longer life expectancy. Therefore, the sales of desktop PC LCD panels suppress other sales afterward. The competition within the desktop PC industry is fierce as each desktop PC firm struggles to get a bigger share of the market.

Conversely, the self-influence coefficient of mobile PC LCD panel b1 itself is negative, indicating the word-of-mouth of mobile PC consumers. Incumbent mobile PC consumers will persuade other consumers to purchase mobile PCs. As the mobile PCs offer users the convenience of not being confined to specific locations and new generations of mobile PCs continue to launch the market, consumers might continue to buy a second or a third mobile PC. As a result, a sale of mobile PC will induce more sales of mobile PCs. Even though the mobile PC market is squeezed by desktop PC, the mobile PC production still has positive strength to assist its own growth of sales. As the sales of mobile PCs enhance their sales growth, the mobile PC LCD panels show similar phenomena. In terms of adjusted R2, the Lotka–Volterra model is very close to one, indicating that the sales volumes of both mobile PC and desktop PC LCD panels can be properly explained by the Lotka–Volterra model because the sales interactions between mobile and desktop PC LCD panels are considered.

sec.p: Figures 2 and 3 depict the actual and predicted cumulative sale volumes using the proposed Lotka–Volterra model for sale volumes of mobile PC and desktop PC panels, respectively, in the test periods. Obviously, the forecasted value is extremely close to the actual sales volumes. The interaction among sales of mobile and desktop PC LCD panels can be explained by using the proposed Lotka–Volterra model.

sec.p: Analytical results indicate that MAPE of the predicted cumulative sale volumes of the proposed Lotka–Volterra model in the test period are 7.95% and 5.70% for mobile PC and desktop PC LCD panels, respectively, during the test period. Both MAPEs of these two products are lower than 10%. Notably, the sales volumes forecasted by the proposed model are well correlated to the actual sale volumes. According to the criteria of Martin and Witt (1989), the predictive ability is excellent. Analytical results demonstrate the forecast accuracy of the proposed Lotka–Volterra model in predicting the sale performance of mobile PC and desktop PC LCD panels.

sec.title: Analysis Results of Equilibrium Points
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the trajectory of actual quarterly sales volumes prior to 2011 and the estimated quarterly sales volumes subsequent to 2011. In this figure, the area on the left side of line dX / dt = 0 represents the region where quarterly sales of desktop PC increase (dX / dt > 0). Similarly, the area on the bottom side of line dY / dt = 0 represents the region where quarter sales of mobile PC increase (dY / dt > 0). For the fourth quarter of 2010, 51,958 thousand units of desktop PC and 66,249 thousand units of mobile PC were shipped. Those numbers correspond to a point where the two PC LCD panel sales have not yet reached their equilibrium point (59,269 and 79,503 thousand pieces, respectively). Figure 4 has demonstrated that quarterly sale trajectory eventually converges to the levels of equilibrium point, representing the stability of the equilibrium point.

Furthermore, Figure 5 plots the time series as X-axis and predicted quarterly sales as Y-axis. Notably, even now neither mobile PC LCD panel nor desktop PC LCD panel sales diffusion has reached the equilibrium point. For mobile PC and desktop PC LCD panels, the quarterly sale volume does not reach its sales peak right away, but rather it increases gradually with time. Prior to 2008, the quarterly sale volume of mobile PC and desktop PC LCD panels increases gradually, but from 2008 to 2010, the sale growth of mobile PC LCD panels far surpasses that of desktop PC LCD panels. Especially after Apple launched tablets (iPad) in 2010, the growth in mobile PC sales volume becomes steeper, surpassing desktop PC. Until 2020, the quarterly sales volume between the two will be maintained stably at 59,269 thousand units for the quarterly sale of desktop LCD panels and 79,503 thousand pieces for that of mobile LCD panels. These sales volumes of 59,269 thousand pieces and 79,503 thousand pieces for desktop and mobile PC LCD panels, respectively, are the same as the values of equilibrium point in Figure 4. This result implies that customer loyalty and satisfaction will change with the LCD panel innovations of the mobile PC.

sec.p: Traditional notebook PC employs the flip-open clamshell design with keyboards, whereas the tablet PC is simply a single, flat touch screen. The iPad, which is much thinner and more power-saving without keyboards, destructively impacted on notebook PC’s market with its brand new innovations. As Microsoft has started to strongly support touch screen operations in Windows 7 and more so in Windows 8 Metro where it is especially designed for touch screen operations, most major PC enterprises have been tirelessly developing various generation designs to make the touch screen more natural, convenient, and user-friendly. As the new technology of touch panel embedded in mobile PC panels became popular, the sales volumes of mobile PC LCD panels experienced a steeper growth than that of desktop PC LCD panels from 2008 to 2010 (Figure 5). Consistent with the hypothesis of sailing ship (Sahal, 1979), desktop PC LCD panel requires innovative technology such as 3D monitor, ultrathin, and touch screen to boost the market share of desktop PC LCD panels.

sec.title: Robust Tests
sec.p: The “Method” section estimated the parameter values from the first quarter of 2001 to fourth quarter of 2010. This section performs the robust tests to reestimate the parameter values over different sample periods, from the first quarter of 2001 to the first, second, and third quarter of 2011. In other words, parameter estimation began from the first quarter of 2001 to the fourth quarter of 2010 and added these three subsequent periods to produce three sets of estimation intervals to conduct the robust tests. This work compares the four sets of the parameter values estimated by the four estimation intervals: the first quarter of 2001 to the fourth quarter of 2010 and to the first, second, and third quarter of 2011, respectively. If all four sets of optimized parameters using different sample periods for parameter optimization were similar, the stability of the model would be confirmed.

Table 4 lists the four sets of estimated coefficient and t-statistics for the four different estimation intervals. Table 4 shows that the signs of these four sets of parameters are identical, and the parameter values or the statistical significance levels of these four sets of parameter values are approximate. The results of robust tests exhibit that different estimation intervals yield similar results of estimated parameters. Negative coefficients

sec.p: Also, Table 4 shows that the R2 values are similar among four different estimation intervals in robust tests, suggesting the similarity in explanatory power of the models constructed by different estimation intervals. Regarding the findings of equilibrium analysis, the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix at the four sets of equilibrium points are all negative, indicating that the long-term prediction results remain similar no matter how long the estimation intervals have been accounted for in estimating parameters. This once again suggests that the empirical results of our proposed model are reliable. Hritonenko and Yatsenko (1999) stated that the equilibrium points can be stable only if the real parts of the eigenvalues are negative. The fact that both eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix at the equilibrium point are negative proves the stability of the equilibrium point. The quarterly sales trajectory of mobile and desktop PC LCD panels eventually converges to the equilibrium point.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Previous studies utilized Bass diffusion theory to analyze commodity diffusion. However, such Bass models cannot effectively interpret market evolutions of this commodity as the model ignores interlevel reciprocal effects on the product diffusion process. Thus, this work uses the Lotka–Volterra model to investigate the dependence between mobile and desktop PC LCD panel sale volumes in the LCD industry. Empirical results show that the Lotka–Volterra model can be used to determine the reciprocal influence among sales of these two products.

Analytical results demonstrate a commensalism relationship between desktop and mobile PC panels. Sale volumes of mobile PC LCD panels promote those of desktop LCD panels, whereas the sale volumes of desktop LCD panels fail to significantly affect those of mobile LCD panels. A possible explanation for this phenomenon is that due to the emerging trend of mobile commerce, mobile audio/video, and mobile office, office workers tend to choose mobile PCs as their first purchase. Then, to acquire greater computing capacity, they will purchase desktop PCs following their first purchase. As mobile PCs in fact promote the sales of desktop PCs, the sale of both panel types shows a commensalism relationship.

The results of Lyapunov function show that the trajectory of the predicted PC LCD panel sales fulfills the stable conditions of the equilibrium point and finally converges to an equilibrium point. From 2008 and 2010, the sales volumes of mobile PC LCD panels far surpass that of desktop PC. Mobile PC enterprises launched a series of product innovations combining the functions of tablet PC with notebooks. After 2008, the utility mobile PCs have expanded to include multiple functions, including telecommunication, photography, word processing, audio-video, and entertainment. This advantage of versatility influences the mobile PC consumers to continue spreading positive word-of-mouth. Thus, the growth in mobile PC sales volume becomes steeper, surpassing desktop PC, resulting in a much greater market share growth for mobile PC LCD panel than for desktop PC. The quarterly sales volume will reach a stable level at 59,269 units for the quarterly sale of desktop PC LCD panels and 79,503 units for the quarterly sale of mobile PC LCD panels. This result implies that customer loyalty and satisfaction will change with the LCD panel innovations of the mobile PCs. Finally, the Lotka–Volterra model performs well in fitness and forecast accuracy because it considers the relationships between mobile and desktop PC LCD panel sales, which conforms to the manufacturing and consumption practices.

We employed segment reporting information and developed a novel Lotka–Volterra model that allows academics and practitioners to better make capital or R&D investment decisions beyond what was possible in previous methods. The proposed predictive model represents a major step forward in the fields of management accounting, highlighted by the following three aspects: unique data, model specification, and applicability to industrial analysis. In reference to unique data, this work transforms the sales volume data of specific products in all company’s segment reports into the global sales volume subject to the specific product. Previous accounting studies that employ total sales revenues summarized by all the products in the whole company from income statements fail to measure the performance subject to specific product (e.g., Behn & Riley, 1999; Leitch & Lamminmaki, 2011). To overcome the drawback of previous study and precisely quantify the collaborations among different products, this work utilizes sales information of mobile and desktop PC LCD panels as quantitative data to state the sale dependency across various products.

Referring to model specifications, this study is the first to construct a model that incorporates interactive relationships among various products. Based on the results of this study, we suggest that mobile and desktop PC LCD panel sales in the LCD industry coexist in a relationship of competition and cooperation. Unlike the conventional Bass model used in previous research (Tsai, 2013), the proposed method eliminates the restrictive assumption that mobile and desktop PCs are unrelated. The specifications of the proposed model are more in line with reality compared with the conventional Bass model.

For applicability in management, our proposed modified model can be applied to forecast the product interactions between specified products in other high-tech industries. LCD panels and PCs are currently the most frequently innovated product with the shortest product life cycle. Other high-tech products, such as TFT-LCD, computers, communications, information technology, and consumer electronics, display the same characteristics as the PCs and LCDs with regard to capital overhead and long-term cost recovery. Thus, the proposed model is applicable to forecasting these high-tech products as well. This work makes a considerable contribution to the applications related to management accounting, technology management, and industrial analysis.
